metadata.title: Critical Review and Uncertainty Analysis of Factors Influencing Influenza Transmission

body_text.text: The second-dimension of the Monte Carlo simulation is repeated B times. In each trial, samples of size N = 96 are drawn from the parametric (Ψ) distributions. For example, in the ith trial, where i ∈ [1, B] , 96 values are drawn from the Lognormal (ψ i ) distribution, and the ordered values are denoted y i = {y i,1 , y i,2 , . . . , y i,96 }. The mean value of the population y i is denotedȳ i . The overall mean cough frequency is the mean of theȳ i , where i = {1, 2, . . . , B}, and the standard error in that estimate is the standard deviation in theȳ i .

The y i can be represented as a matrix, Y, which has B = 10 4 rows and N = 96 columns. Due to the ordering of the y i , in each of the i rows of Y, cough frequencies in the jth column correspond to the j N th percentile of a sampled cumulative distribution of cough frequency. The B values in the jth column describe variability in the j N th percentile of the cumulative distribution of cough frequency. The median cumulative distribution equals to the median cough frequency in each of the N columns. Similarly, the central 90% range is defined by the 5th and 95th percentiles (the B × 0.05 and B × 0.95 entries in the ordered values) in each of the the N columns of Y.

Treanor et al (4) used nose/throat swabs, extracted with 3 mL of fluid, to measure the concentration of infectious influenza virus in 71 adults presenting within 36 h of onset of influenza symptoms, who were otherwise healthy and were seropositive for seasonal influenza A or B viruses. At baseline, 100% (71/71) of the participants shed virus, with median virus concentration 3.5 log 10 TCID 50 per mL extraction fluid (equivalently, 10 3.5 TCID 50 /mL), and range [0.5, 6.6 log 10 TCID 50 /mL]. To these log 10 concentration data, I fit a Normal distribution, equating the reported median with the distribution mean. I assumed the reported range equaled the 5th and 95th percentiles of the distribution (z = ±1.645), and took the standard deviation of the distribution to be equal to the mean value of the estimates from each tail s = 1.56 log 10 TCID 50 /mL (CV = 45%). The next day, 85% (60/71) participants shed virus with median virus concentration 2.3 log 10 TCID 50 /mL, and range [0.0. 5.5 log 10 TCID 50 /mL]. The Normal distribution parameters were estimated as previously, such that s = 1.40 log 10 TCID 50 /mL (CV = 61%). I could find no data relating swab sample concentrations to virus concentrations in respiratory secretions, so I accounted for dilution to 3 mL during sample extraction I added log 10 3 (0.48) to the mean log 10 concentrations, and adjusted the standard deviations to maintain the CV. The resulting probability distributions of infectious influenza in respiratory secretions are: Normal (µ = 3.98, σ = 1.77 log 10 TCID 50 /mL) at baseline, and Normal (µ = 2.78, σ = 1.69 log 10 TCID 50 /mL) at day 1.

Lee et al (5) collected nasal wash specimens from 88 patients admitted to the hospital on symptom days 1-6 prior to treatment. Patients presenting on symptom days 1-4 had mean (standard deviation) viral concentrations in their nasal wash specimens: 6.3 (s = 1.37), 5.84 (s = 1.13), 4.50 (s = 1.87), and 4.54 (s = 2.09) log 10 RNA copies per mL respectively. Among 16 outpatients who presented on symptom days 1-2 with influenza A infections, the mean influenza virus concentration in nasal wash specimens was 4.51 (s = 1.67) log 10 RNA copies/mL. (5) Nasal washing has been found to dilute rhinovirus concentrations approximately one order of magnitude relative to the concentration in the nasal fluid. (6) The number of influenza A and B (PR 8 and Lee strains) per TCID 50 has been found to range 10 2 -10 4 , such that, on average, influenza genomes are 1,000 times more numerous than TCID 50 . (7, 8) Therefore I added 1 to the reported log 10 concentrations to account for dilution, and subtracted 3 to account for the number of genomes per log 10 TCID 50 to give log 10 TCID 50 per mL of respiratory secretions; and adjusted the standard deviation to maintain the same coefficient of variation. The resulting probability distributions of influenza log 10 TCID 50 in respiratory secretions are: Normal (µ = 4.30, σ = 0.93 log 10 TCID 50 /mL), Normal (µ = 3.84, σ = 0.74 log 10 TCID 50 /mL), Normal (µ = 2.50, σ = 1.03 log 10 TCID 50 /mL), and Normal (µ = 2.54, σ = 1.17 log 10 TCID 50 /mL) at symptom days 1-4, respectively, for hospitalized patients; and Normal (µ = 2.51, σ = 1.93 log 10 TCID 50 /mL) for outpatients.

For the uncertainty analysis the sample size was determined as follows. I assumed that hospitalized patients studied by Lee et al (5) had equal probability of presenting on each day, such that 59 persons (foursixths of the 88 persons) presented on symptom days 1-4. Including the 71 persons sampled by Treanor et al, (4) and the 16 outpatients sampled by Lee et al, (5) the total sample population is N = 146.

For comparison, the cumulative distribution functions estimated for low (<50% RH, N = 32) and high relative humidities (≥ 50% RH, N = 34) separately, using the one-dimensional Monte Carlo simulation, are presented in Figure 1 . The jagged distributions clearly show discontinuity in the data. For both data sets, the uncertainty ranges are approximately symmetric around the median, but are much narrower below than above the 50th percentiles of the cumulative distributions. At low relative humidity, the overall mean±s e inactivation rate is 0.39 ± 0.075 h −1 . The 50th percentile of the cumulative distribution function has median inactivation rate 0.

Given the sparsity of data, I used a bootstrap test to determine the likelihood that the observed variation by virus type be explained by chance. To explain, consider the inactivation of influenza A on B on pajamas, k = 0.117 and k = 0.039 h −1 (Table  II of Distribution of influenza A virus inactivation rate in air at room temperature at low relative humidity (<50%) and high relative humidity (≥ 50%). (10, 9) The uncertainty analysis used a one-dimensional Monte Carlo simulation and N = 32 or N = 34 for low and high relative humidity, respectively.
body_text.section: Inactivation on Porous Substrates: Bootstrap Analyses

body_text.text: Note, σ < s. To implement the test, I drew two random samples from this Normal (µ = 0.225, σ = 0.074 h −1 ) distribution, and computed the sample standard deviation,ŝ. Of 10 4 trials, 404 (4%) trials hadŝ ≥ s. If the inactivation rates for influenza A and B are truly from this Normal (µ, σ) distribution, the more frequently the sampled standard deviation should be as large or larger than the measured standard deviation. The statistical criterion is: p = 1 B B b=1 I(ŝ b ≥ s) ≥ 0.05, where I is an indicator variable equal to 1 when the inequality is true, and 0 otherwise. For pajamas, p = 0.04, and we reject the hypothesis that the measured k are from the same Normal (µ, σ) distribution. For magazine, tissue, handkerchief and banknote substrates, p = 0.75, p = 0.03, p = 0.04, p = 0.07, respectively; such that only for magazine is there no evidence that the inactivation rates for influenza A and B are not from the same distribution. If CV = 50%, p > 0.05 (0.16-0.83) for all substrates. These results indicate that the inactivation rate of influenza A and B may not be the same on each substrate, unless the true variability has CV >33%.
body_text.section: Inactivation on Porous Substrates: Bootstrap Analyses

body_text.text: I used a similar approach to determine if the variability observed across substrate type could be explained by chance. For influenza A, I assumed the inactivation rate was described by a Normal (µ = 0.592, σ = 0.195 h −1 ) distribution, where µ equals the average of the inactivation rates on the 5 substrates (k, Table II of main text), and σ = µ×0.33 h −1 , based on CV = 33%. The standard deviation in the inactivation rates for each substrate is s = 0.426 h −1 . Based on 5 samples drawn from this Normal distribution, only 0.1% hadŝ ≥ s, giving p = 0.001, and providing evidence to reject the hypothesis that the inactivation rate of influenza A on all substrates is from the specified Normal distribution. When CV = 50% is assumed, however, σ = µ × 0.50 = 0.296 h −1 , and p = 0.085. Similarly, for influenza B, I used a Normal (µ = 0.542, σ = 0.179 h −1 ) distribution. The standard deviation in the inactivation rates on the 5 substrates is s = 0.349 h −1 . Based on 5 samples drawn from this Normal distribution, only 0.4% had s ≥ s, giving p = 0.004, and providing evidence to reject the hypothesis that the inactivation rate of influenza B on all substrates is described by the specified Normal distribution. When CV = 50% is assumed, however, σ = µ × 0.50 = 0.271 h −1 , and p = 0.150. Results are similar when all data (influenza A and B) are combined: with CV = 33% giving p = 0.001, and CV = 50% giving p = 0.090.
body_text.section: Inactivation on Porous Substrates: Bootstrap Analyses

body_text.text: As with inactivation rates on porous substrates, I used a bootstrap procedure to test if the inactivation rate on each substrate differed by virus strain. On steel, random samples of size 2 were drawn from the Normal (µ = 0.189, σ = 0.089 h −1 ), where µ equals the average of the inactivation rates on each substrate (k, Table II of main text), and σ = µ×0.47, based on CV = 47%. The standard deviation of the k is s = 0.075 h −1 . Of the 10 4 samples, 22% had s ≥ s, such that p = 0.221, and providing no evidence to reject that the inactivation rates of influenza A and B on steel are from the specified distribution. On plastic, the specified distribution is Normal (µ = 0.280, σ = 0.132 h −1 ). The standard deviation of the k is s = 0.054 h −1 . Of the 10 4 samples, 42% hadŝ ≥ s, such that p = 0.416. Similarly on glass at 20% RH and at 84%, the bootstrap procedure gave p = 0.775 and p = 0.655, respectively, providing no evidence to reject the hypothesis that the inactivation rates for the swine and WS strains of influenza A are from the specified distribution, characterized by CV = 47%.
body_text.section: Inactivation on Non-Porous Substrates: Bootstrap Analyses

body_text.text: Variability across substrate type was also explored. The mean inactivation rate across all substrates and virus types is 1.14, such that with CV = 47%, the hypothesized true distribution is Normal (µ = 1.14, σ = 0.534). Note, σ is smaller than the standard deviation in the k values, s = 1.19 h −1 . Of the 10 4 samples of size 10 drawn from this Normal distribution, all hadŝ < s (p < 0.001), providing strong evidence that that data do not come from the specified Normal distribution, with CV = 47%. However, when inactivation rates on steel and plastic, only, were combined, there was no evidence to reject the hypothesis that the data are from the specified Normal (µ = 1.64, σ = 0.771 h −1 ) distribution, as nearly 50% of samples of size 4 had s ≥ s, where s = 0.075 h −1 (p = 0.495). And when inactivation rates on glass, only, were combined, there was no evidence to reject the hypothesis that the data are from the specified Normal (µ = 2.12, σ = 0.996 h −1 ) distribution as nearly 61% of samples of size 4 hadŝ ≥ s, where s = 0.872 h −1 (p = 0.693).
body_text.section: Inactivation on Non-Porous Substrates: Bootstrap Analyses
